Culturally? Surely and everywhere on every level. Neither Hungarian neither them is Finno-Ugric however. The Hungarian language is as much related to Proto-Turks with Proto-Finns because of living close to each, but basically those are getting mixed from our langauge which is from the Scythian mainlands and with some Mesopotamian structure too. Genetically? The archeogenetics of 9th century Hungrian graves show clear Scythian origin - among others. It was already a mixed population.These are the markers found: R1aZ2123 and R1aZ2124 - also this is the one found in bloodline of Béla III king from the Turul dynasty is a big number appearance. Found together with J1, R1BL23, Q1A, C2 and N3A2 in less and less numbers. Most of these variants either found in Scythian, Proto-scythian graves only so far and some is mongoloid (only a single C2 for example). Over 30% is from these in which the two first dominate, with others appearing.I2A1A2B is really high number on its own and appear in masses through archeo-genetic samples of early Hungarians. This is the second biggest thing and the biggest on its own unlike the above group. This is actually really ancient and older than Scythian and is found in the Baden-Cucuteni culture findings in biggest numbers earlier than 9th century early Hungarians. Around 20% of the population of them belonged to this single group.R1a CTS1112 also appears measurably. This is today also found in Slavs, but in early times this is linked with “Eastern Corded ware culture”. Having 13% of this in 9th century Hungarian graves.R1b U106I1 is smaller in quantity than the above. This is likely related to early German or Goth tribes (12,8% in Early Hungarians).N3A4: This we have less than 9% of in the 9th century graves and found in Kama-Finnic populations who once travelled northwards from the south-mid Ural region. Not for sure yet, small in number. Also a later branch of this is found in early Manysi people, but we do not have their mutation in our graves, just a much earlier variety depicting they branched off from the ones we have to some amount.EV13: Found in Subartu culture graves - 7% hereRbU152: Celts and sometimes latinized Celts - 3%G2A2B and J2A1A: minor apperance…Some of these also link to Mesopotamia, like J1 and J2 and some others, but later also found in Jazig and Alan tribes too along other markers.Quite recent measurements from Neparáczky team from Hungarian research institute and more details will follow. Practically no links with Northern Ural areas DNA and only N3 can in any ways link a bit towards “Manysi” cultures, but instead of finding their own archeogenetic branch what we have found is an earlier variety from which “Manysi” have branched off and pretty small in numbers we found this.Also these high number of I2A1A2B and R1aZ2123/24 are found in typical Hungarian graves with traditional arctifacts of 9th century Hungarians and mostly from the Karos cemetery and not remains of some “previously local population” or if they are, then of the same culture and same personal status as the other graves. Practcically 100% Hungarian. As usual with horse riding scythians the markers are somewhat mixed even in graves having same culture and artifacts and nearby each other and DNA will be sequenced further because big groups like “R1a”, “J” and “I2″ practically holds no information as they are too broad to properly understand movements and nationalities. Also more snapshots are to be taken from multiple time periods to see movements properly. This is practically the same as our own Chronicles says and surely shows a continuity.
